author: pipermerriam
content: The "qualifications" requirements are intentionally loosely defined.  This is because when you look at the core developers, I'm not sure that there's very many objectively measurable attributes that are shared across the team.  There are core devs who didn't attend university.  There's plenty who did but have no formal computer science background.  There are some that don't have any extensive prior work experience.   See this section for my best stab at a description of what it takes: https://github.com/ethereum-cdap/cohort-zero/blob/main/program-details.md#who-is-it-for

content: Hi <@!364458974906548225>. I have a question for consensus mechanism.  Now I have some humbergers, and you want to use 1 ETH to buy a humberger from me. Then we agreed offline. You give me 1 ETH, and I will give you a humberger. It seems OK. But let's consider another scenario. You keep your promises, and transfer 1 ETH to my wallet. But I'm a bad man. When I confirmed the transaction, Iâ€˜m immediately running away with my humbergers. Now the consensus mechanism in Ethereum cannot restrain my behavior. So how cryptocurrency to build a connection with the real world?

author: lightclient
content: Connecting the blockchain world and the real world is a very difficult problem. In the scenario you laid out, nothing can be done besides take it up with the local authorities and hope the justice system can resolve the issue. There are some *potential* mechanisms to resolve disputes between the blockchain and the real world, but none of them fool proof. Checkout Kleros as an example. The issue is that generally you'll need to stake at minimum the total amount of volume you need to be covered for - so suppose in your example, you dispute window ends after 24 hours. That means the burger provider would need to stake enough funds to cover all 24 hours worth of transactions. Insurance protocols might be able to reduce that burden, but now we're starting to get out of the scope of the original post ðŸ™‚

author: ryan5th_l6840
content:
Multisig or escrow smart contracts help with transaction trust a little. 

Invoicing is another way of enforcing trust. 

They help bridge to the real world by outlining exactly what each party expects both inside and outside the block chain, and recording when each party confirms a positive or negative transaction, and distributing crypto according to contract specs. Escrows are especially effective I think.

author: pipermerriam
content: I'll point out that this line of discussion is loosely relevant, but it's mostly applicable to the application layer, i.e. people who want to build "things" on top of the protocol.  These are often good ways to learn about the protocol itself, but they are also only tangentially related to the core protocol.  If you'd like to discuss this type of thing, I'll encourage it to happen in <#595721451651465227> or to ensure that your discussion is in some way directly related to the core protocol itself.
